metadata.title: Outline views | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Human Interface Guidelines documentation page describing outline views - a UI component that presents hierarchical data in a scrolling list of cells organized into columns and rows. The document covers best practices, platform considerations, and related resources for implementing outline views in macOS applications.
metadata.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

content.text: Outline views
An outline view presents hierarchical data in a scrolling list of cells that are organized into columns and rows.

content.description: A macOS Finder window showing an outline view with a hierarchical file system structure. The window displays a table with four columns: Name, Date Modified, Size, and Kind. The content shows folders and image files with disclosure triangles for expandable folders.
content.composition: A rectangular window with a light gray header row containing column titles, followed by alternating white and light gray rows showing file system items. Folders have disclosure triangles (chevrons) on the left that can be expanded to show nested content.
content.technicalDetails: macOS Finder application in outline/list view mode showing file browser interface
content.contextualRelevance: This image illustrates the primary example of an outline view in macOS - the Finder's list view. It demonstrates the key features discussed in the documentation: hierarchical data display, multiple columns with different data types, disclosure triangles for expanding/collapsing folders, and column headers.

visualElements.disclosureTriangles: Chevron-style triangles (>) pointing right when collapsed, pointing down (v) when expanded
visualElements.fileIcons: Small colored icons representing file types - blue folder icon for folders, orange/yellow image icon for PNG files
visualElements.rowSelection: Selected row (Image A) has a coral/salmon colored background highlight
visualElements.rowAlternation: Subtle alternating background colors for rows

content.text: An outline view includes at least one column that contains primary hierarchical data, such as a set of parent containers and their children. You can add columns, as needed, to display attributes that supplement the primary data; for example, sizes and modification dates. Parent containers have disclosure triangles that expand to reveal their children.
Finder windows offer an outline view for navigating the file system.
Outline views work well to display text-based content and often appear in the leading side of a split view, with related content on the opposite side.
Best practices
Use a table instead of an outline view to present data that's not hierarchical.
content.followUpText: For guidance, see Lists and tables.

content.text: Expose data hierarchy in the first column only.
content.followUpText: Other columns can display attributes that apply to the hierarchical data in the primary column.

content.text: Use descriptive column headings to provide context.
content.followUpText: Use nouns or short noun phrases with title-style capitalization and no punctuation; in particular, avoid adding a trailing colon. Always provide column headings in a multi-column outline view. If you don't include a column heading in a single-column outline view, use a label or other means to make sure there's enough context.

content.text: Consider letting people click column headings to sort an outline view.
content.followUpText: In a sortable outline view, people can click a column heading to perform an ascending or descending sort based on that column. You can implement additional sorting based on secondary columns behind the scenes, if necessary. If people click the primary column heading, sorting occurs at each hierarchy level. For example, in the Finder, all top-level folders are sorted, then the items within each folder are sorted. If people click the heading of a column that's already sorted, the folders and their contents are sorted again in the opposite direction.

content.text: Let people resize columns.
content.followUpText: Data displayed in an outline view often varies in width. It's important to let people adjust column width as needed to reveal data that's wider than the column.

content.text: Make it easy for people to expand or collapse nested containers.
content.followUpText: For example, clicking a disclosure triangle for a folder in a Finder window expands only that folder. However, Option-clicking the disclosure triangle expands all of its subfolders.

content.text: Retain people's expansion choices.
content.followUpText: If people expand various levels of an outline view to reach a specific item, store the state so you can display it again the next time. This way, people won't need to navigate back to the same place again.

content.text: Consider using alternating row colors in multi-column outline views.
content.followUpText: Alternating colors can make it easier for people to track row values across columns, especially in wide outline views.

content.text: Let people edit data if it makes sense in your app.
content.followUpText: In an editable outline view cell, people expect to be able to single-click a cell to edit its contents. Note that a cell can respond differently to a double click. For example, an outline view listing files might let people single-click a file's name to edit it, but double-click a file's name to open the file. You can also let people reorder, add, and remove rows if it would be useful.

content.text: Consider using a centered ellipsis to truncate cell text instead of clipping it.
content.followUpText: An ellipsis in the middle preserves the beginning and end of the cell text, which can make the content more distinct and recognizable than clipped text.

content.text: Consider offering a search field to help people find values quickly in a lengthy outline view.
content.followUpText: Windows with an outline view as the primary feature often include a search field in the toolbar. For guidance, see Search fields.

content.text: Platform considerations
Not supported in iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, visionOS, or watchOS.

Related
Developer documentation

content.composition: Dark gradient background with colorful abstract geometric shapes (likely representing stacks, grids, and outlines) and SwiftUI branding
content.technicalDetails: WWDC video session thumbnail, clickable to play video
textInImage: Stacks, Grids, and Outlines in SwiftUI

pages.pageSummary: This is the Apple Human Interface Guidelines page for Outline views, a macOS-only UI component for displaying hierarchical data in columns and rows. The page provides a definition, visual example from Finder, 11 best practices for implementation, platform availability notes, and links to related documentation including SwiftUI OutlineGroup and AppKit NSOutlineView.

crossPageElements.runningFooters: Apple Developer comprehensive footer with site navigation

sections.title: Outline views
sections.summary: Introduction defining outline views as a UI component for presenting hierarchical data in scrolling lists organized into columns and rows, with a visual example from macOS Finder.

sections.title: Best practices

subsections.title: Data hierarchy guidance
subsections.summary: Use tables for non-hierarchical data; expose hierarchy in first column only

subsections.title: Column management
subsections.summary: Use descriptive headings, enable sorting, allow resizing

subsections.title: Expansion behavior
subsections.summary: Support easy expand/collapse, retain expansion state, support Option-click for recursive expansion

subsections.title: Visual design
subsections.summary: Consider alternating row colors, use centered ellipsis for truncation

subsections.title: Editing and interaction
subsections.summary: Support single-click editing, differentiate double-click behavior, allow reordering

subsections.title: Search functionality
subsections.summary: Offer search field for lengthy outline views

sections.summary: Eleven best practices covering hierarchy display, column management, user interaction, visual design, and search capabilities for outline views.

sections.title: Platform considerations
sections.summary: Notes that outline views are only supported on macOS; not available on iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, visionOS, or watchOS.

sections.title: Resources

subsections.title: Related
subsections.summary: Links to Column views, Lists and tables, and Split views HIG pages

subsections.title: Developer documentation
subsections.summary: Links to OutlineGroup (SwiftUI) and NSOutlineView (AppKit) documentation

subsections.title: Videos
subsections.summary: Link to WWDC session 'Stacks, Grids, and Outlines in SwiftUI'

sections.summary: Related HIG topics, developer API documentation, and WWDC video resources.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document follows Apple's standard HIG page structure: starts with a title and brief definition, shows a visual example (Finder window), provides detailed best practices organized by topic, notes platform availability, and concludes with related resources including documentation links and WWDC videos. The sidebar provides navigation context within the broader Design Guidelines.

keyTerms.definition: A UI component that presents hierarchical data in a scrolling list of cells organized into columns and rows
A chevron-style control that expands or collapses to reveal or hide child items in a hierarchical view
Data organized in parent-child relationships, such as folders containing files or nested categories
A layout pattern where outline views often appear in the leading side with related content on the opposite side
SwiftUI component for creating outline views
AppKit class for creating outline views in macOS applications
Labels at the top of columns that provide context and may enable sorting
Capitalization format recommended for column headings (nouns/short noun phrases)
Text truncation technique that preserves beginning and end of text

keyFindings: Outline views are macOS-only - not supported on iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, visionOS, or watchOS
Hierarchy should only be displayed in the first column; other columns show supplementary attributes
Option-clicking a disclosure triangle should expand all nested subfolders recursively
User expansion state should be persisted and restored between sessions
Single-click should edit cell content; double-click can have different behavior (e.g., open file)
Centered ellipsis truncation is preferred over clipping for better text recognizability
Outline views work well in the leading side of split views
Column headings should use title-style capitalization with no punctuation or trailing colons
Sortable outline views should support clicking column headings for ascending/descending sort
Alternating row colors help users track values across columns in wide views

interactionPatterns.singleClick: Edit cell content or select item
interactionPatterns.doubleClick: Open item or perform primary action

designDecisions.rationale: Use outline view only for hierarchical data; use table for non-hierarchical data
Always provide column headings in multi-column views; single-column views may omit if context is clear
Store user's expansion choices to prevent repeated navigation to the same location
Use in multi-column views to help track values across columns, especially in wide views
Centered ellipsis preserves recognizability better than clipping by keeping start and end of text
Include search field in toolbar for lengthy outline views to help users find values quickly

verbatimTextContent.subheading: An outline view presents hierarchical data in a scrolling list of cells that are organized into columns and rows.
verbatimTextContent.introductionParagraph1: An outline view includes at least one column that contains primary hierarchical data, such as a set of parent containers and their children. You can add columns, as needed, to display attributes that supplement the primary data; for example, sizes and modification dates. Parent containers have disclosure triangles that expand to reveal their children.

bestPractices.title: Use a table instead of an outline view to present data that's not hierarchical.
bestPractices.detail: For guidance, see Lists and tables.

bestPractices.title: Expose data hierarchy in the first column only.
bestPractices.detail: Other columns can display attributes that apply to the hierarchical data in the primary column.

bestPractices.title: Use descriptive column headings to provide context.
bestPractices.detail: Use nouns or short noun phrases with title-style capitalization and no punctuation; in particular, avoid adding a trailing colon. Always provide column headings in a multi-column outline view. If you don't include a column heading in a single-column outline view, use a label or other means to make sure there's enough context.

bestPractices.title: Consider letting people click column headings to sort an outline view.
bestPractices.detail: In a sortable outline view, people can click a column heading to perform an ascending or descending sort based on that column. You can implement additional sorting based on secondary columns behind the scenes, if necessary. If people click the primary column heading, sorting occurs at each hierarchy level. For example, in the Finder, all top-level folders are sorted, then the items within each folder are sorted. If people click the heading of a column that's already sorted, the folders and their contents are sorted again in the opposite direction.

bestPractices.title: Let people resize columns.
bestPractices.detail: Data displayed in an outline view often varies in width. It's important to let people adjust column width as needed to reveal data that's wider than the column.

bestPractices.title: Make it easy for people to expand or collapse nested containers.
bestPractices.detail: For example, clicking a disclosure triangle for a folder in a Finder window expands only that folder. However, Option-clicking the disclosure triangle expands all of its subfolders.

bestPractices.title: Retain people's expansion choices.
bestPractices.detail: If people expand various levels of an outline view to reach a specific item, store the state so you can display it again the next time. This way, people won't need to navigate back to the same place again.

bestPractices.title: Consider using alternating row colors in multi-column outline views.
bestPractices.detail: Alternating colors can make it easier for people to track row values across columns, especially in wide outline views.

bestPractices.title: Let people edit data if it makes sense in your app.
bestPractices.detail: In an editable outline view cell, people expect to be able to single-click a cell to edit its contents. Note that a cell can respond differently to a double click. For example, an outline view listing files might let people single-click a file's name to edit it, but double-click a file's name to open the file. You can also let people reorder, add, and remove rows if it would be useful.

bestPractices.title: Consider using a centered ellipsis to truncate cell text instead of clipping it.
bestPractices.detail: An ellipsis in the middle preserves the beginning and end of the cell text, which can make the content more distinct and recognizable than clipped text.

bestPractices.title: Consider offering a search field to help people find values quickly in a lengthy outline view.
bestPractices.detail: Windows with an outline view as the primary feature often include a search field in the toolbar. For guidance, see Search fields.
